Hello All,


This build started life as an idea I'd had for a Hin Monk/Rogue/CoT Dexer. My motives were not the purest: I found that every time I tried a Dexer, I reverted to Mick Dagger's awesome Halfling Champion (R20/Cot14/F6), so I thought I'd try for something different that I could play - and if others could as well, so much the better. In a way, it's different from other builds I've posted, in that this one really doesn't get full maturity until later levels, but it's definitely playable throughout (tested to the end of Aielund - level 37), just with a little more caution early on.


Looking through the Legacy Archive, I found 3 similar builds: Empyre65's Skilled Monk (M21/R13/CoT6), ManOWar's Ninja of Torm (M20/R10/CoT10), and Sidious Fell's M20/CoT13/R7 - although this one ended up after discussion being Syrath1001's M20/R10/CoT10. The only one of these that was a halfling build was this last one, the other two being human, and Empyre's also has an Unarmed Strike focus, although is probably the closest to mine in conceptual terms. In the ECB Filter, Valerfor's Hin-Hurricane Ironman Ed. (M25/R5/F10) was the only one that appeared of comparable intent.


The original draft - preliminary version - can be found within the spoiler at the bottom of this post, so that the discussion that follows makes at least some sense.

AC (naked/mundane armor/shield only): 36/36 (+1/+1 Dodge)

The whys and wherefores:

1. Tried to get to Monk 6 asap without delaying rogue levels too much.

2.  ED asap, Level 27.

3. Last rogue dump at Lvl 31 to assure net UMD of 33, adequate to cast all scrolls without failure.

Any more UMD is unnecessary.  Monk's won't be using either class-specific armor, shield or weaponry so, generally-speaking, gear valued over 1M gold will never become an issue.  Your main use will be scrolls, wands and rods.  There may be the occasional class-specific cap, cloak or jewelry item but I am betting the value never breaches the 1M level.

4.  The choice between Mnk21/Rog13 and Mnk20/Rog14 is fairly straight-forward: [+10% move speed, +1 SR and 2 HP] vs. [4 skill points and +1 saves vs. traps].  Universal saves won't change.  Seems automatic to me.

5. I do like the idea of STR14 for a DEXer.  In point of fact, that's usually what I strive for.  But there is a cost for so few levels of CoT and that extra Grt DEX is expensive (No AS).  STR12 is about all I could manage and you certainly don't want to lower WIS AC.  I'd rethink your starting spread, Stagmeister.

6.  My rogue skill allocation assures to be able to recover and set all deadly traps but the gas type.  Unless it is a dedicated trapper, I never waste points on traps that have such poor DCs like those gas have.  But they can still be disarmed at this level.  Only Search is a bit neglected which means you should NOT charge into areas likely trapped using monk speed.  If you are using stealth by default, it should be fine. Shift that lonely point from Locks over if you are so possessed. If there are pockets to pick, perhaps even lower Search another point to get it.

7. This Discipline is not horrible for a DEXer and well worth the investment.  Only very high AB KD/disarm attempts will land.

8. Just beware of taunters. They will mostly succeed in lowering your AC.    And when they do, run around a corner, enter stealth and try to spam multiple hits within a round of Crippling Strikes.  The AB they gained will disappear quickly once that nasty monk APR connects.

All you guys come up with kewl build names.  Mine always suck.  Is there a 3-credit elective I could take to learn to be more "creative"?

edit: ooops!  Just realised you took Wpn Finesse illegally.  It requires BAB +1 so only warrior types can take it on level 1.

Stagmeister wrote:
-- clip --
2. Understood, with a starting DEX of 18 that's bang on. I tried all sorts of starting stats combos - all had CHA at 8; some were CON 12, others 14; some INT 12, others 14; WIS went from 8 to 10 and 12, then back again; STR was always 13 or 14; and DEX always 17 or 18. I settled on low WIS (8) because, unlike DEX, it has no negative impact on Monk AC, and kept STR at 14 because I was desperate for damage (as a traditional STR builder/user) and wasn't really seeing any in the absence of WS/EWS. It was a sort of comfort blanket.
-- clip --

5. See my 2., above. I'm interested in why I should drop 2 from STR to add to WIS - assuming I'm right about no negative impact from a minus WIS score (for Monk AC, at any rate)? Admittedly, a "complete" UMD portfolio won't be achieved until 1 later level, and my Will save will suffer by 1, but is that all? As to the lack of Armour Skin, yes, I recognise the lack of 2 AC is costly, but with a naked AC of 34, does it really make that big a difference when set beside an extra point of damage per successful attack? I know things are trade-offs, but I ain't sure on this one.

--clip --
 
Two points.

That extra point in DEX I allocated for starting abilities cost you an epic feat to achieve the same final level of DEX.  With DEX at 18 and WIS at 8, you can only reach STR 13.

You are not totally correct about the non-negative impact of WIS 8.  All attentive monks realize that carrying Owl pots are a staple of their prowess.  It will boost AC up to +2 along with their DCs (like Stunning Fist, Quivering Palm, and those precious Will saves you seem to treasure).  At WIS 8, you can reach an AC boost of +1, at Wis 10 +2.  Actually, one could even make an argument why WIS 11 is worthwhile for the 25% chance to reach +3 AC (along with the other boosts already mentioned).

In retrospect, I could have swapped Armor Skin and the Grt DEX at Level 30 but decided to try to reach Monk 20 asap since it appeared to be a goal of yours.

And to illuminate your quandry about what feats can be taken as CoT bonus in epic (in no particular order):

ambidexterity, armor prof hvy, armor skin, autoquicken, autosilent, autostill, blind fight, called shot, cleave, dodge, edr, epic prowess, epic spell focus, epic spell pen, epic tough, wf/ewf, ews, great smite, great wis, superior initiative, expertise/imp expertise, great cleave, great smite, imp combat casting, imp critical, , KD/IKD, disarm/imp disarm, imp parry, pa/imp pa, planar turning, pbs, rapid shot, spring attack, stunning fist/imp sf, twf/imp twf, imp ua strike, ww/imp ww, mobility, overcrit, devcrit, wpn prof exotic, wpn finesse.

I don't know about you, but providing access to all the spell-related feats just boggles my mind while CoT bonus doesn't even include SkF or ESkF.  Go figure.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Much appreciated, Hip, thanks.

I've slept on it now (I find rumination less painful lying down), and I guess several choices I made were down to my almost inbred instinct to go STR (eg, Power Attack, STR 14). If I'm building a Dexer, that's what I should be building. And what are the biggies for DEX meleers? Epic Dodge and stonking AC, together with lots of blows delivered. Your build gets ED earlier than my first stab and has better AC, as well as earlier Crippling Strike, so what's not to like?

And double thanks for getting the build to Monk 20 by the mid thirties - yes, I do like me some Perfect Self. I figure that if I'm investing in at least 12 levels of Monk, it seems a bit like cutting your nose off to spite your face not to take it to 20.

To a certain extent there is a law of diminishing returns with only 6 levels of CoT (particularly with negative CHA), but I didn't fancy the XP penalty of taking Fighter (makes more of a difference in SP than PWs, I would think), and Weapon Master needed a whole other set of feats I didn't have room for. I did some head-scratching about Shadow Dancer, but - other than HiPS - I thought there would be too much duplication with Rogue and Monk (eg, I'd have Evasion 3 times over). Bard song would also have been nice, but at the end of the day I knew I needed a couple of bonus feats pre-epic and at least 1 in epic, so CoT it was.

I'll do some cannibalising of your build and feed it into my draft, if that's okay? I'd feel a bit of a fraud lodging it on the Full Epic forum (after I do some proper testing, of course), but I might get away with it if I give proper credit.

Cheers

I think you'll enjoy playing your pint-sized monk, Stagmeister.  Being human can get so boring at times.  You never know when a halfling merchant or other NPC will react differently just because it doesn't need to bend its neck to talk to you.

As far as credit goes, just focus on aspects you've derived from established published builds like those you've already mentioned.  Include both the elements that you gleaned and also the aspects you've steered away from and the reasons.  It just helps to make your own idea more unique that way.  All I did was throw out a hastily-prepared version for comparison's sake because it is faster for me than explaining all the details in verbage. To help get all your synapses firing, hopefully.  Because I'm lazy and always in a rush.  A picture worth... you know.

Remember.  Once you've published your own concept, YOU are the owner, not I.  Which means you need to have the answers and replies ready.  Just make sure all the vitals are there for easy extraction (I am sure you know what that refers to. )

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
This is just by way of an incidental, but I've just spent 3 hours working on the skills distribution by level - and loved it (apart from when my maths buggered things up, of course). I know, I know, it's sad, and could be much easier using these new-fangled lectronixy things, but there's a lot to be said for just sitting there and mulling over priorities. And I'll apologise because many if not all of you know this stuff - I'm just in a sharing mood. That, and I'm giving a rallying cry for pnp - thinking is important!

For instance, when one starts to grasp that 310 skill points ain't enough for what you want, you have to think about why you do want certain skills, and when you want them. In this instance (and using Hip's earlier, very good allocation), I finally decided that my Big Four unassailables were Discipline, Spellcraft, Tumble and UMD - and they would feature whenever they could, up to any finite level. Spellcraft, of course, was cross-classed throughout (ending at level 33 with 18 ranks, summing to 20, and thereby +4 v Spells, to sit alongside the +2 v Spells from being a Hin) and Tumble met its natural end at level 37 (40 taken ranks - +8AC), while UMD reared to a defiant halt at level 31, giving the (now clarified) 33 net ranks, enabling use of pretty well everything.

I then had to think about what I wanted early on in the build, and what could wait. So my second tranche became Search, Disable Trap, and Open Lock - 2 of which were done and dusted by level 3, leaving only Disable Trap to finish with a solitary point at level 19. My thinking was simple: while you might glide over triggered traps in later levels with barely a backward glance, early on they're likely to blow your head off, and that would be a Bad Thing.

Which left Hide, Move Silently, Listen and Set Trap. I understand that at least 3 of these are intrinsic to the build, but I felt I had more scope to manipulate them than any of the others. As it transpired, Hide and Move Silently were a doddle, and went exactly where I wanted them to. Set Traps I'd always regarded as one of them fancy-arse things, but started to like the idea as I went along, so gave it the full charge at level 24. And that left Listen. A perfectly admirable skill - and one I prefer to Spot in the detection stakes (personal preferance). But this was the one I felt could be most used and abused in getting to its full 43 (48) ranks. Didn't have to do it much - the 30s is where it regains its place in the heirarchy, with a final plop of 5 ranks at level 40. But the point is, they'll have to be whispering long before that if my bat-like Hin ears ain't going to hear 'em.

I know I'm preaching to the converted, but others may be looking in, and I know I'd like to know this stuff (unless I've made a bollocks of it, that is).

Off to play, now, so

As it transpired, Hide and Move Silently were a doddle, and went exactly where I wanted them to. Set Traps I'd always regarded as one of them fancy-arse things, but started to like the idea as I went along, so gave it the full charge at level 24.
 
Here's how trap skill allotment works:

First is the +2 synergy with at least 5 ranks in each of DTrap/STrap.

5 ranks in Set Trap results in a final level of 18 once all the DEX has been accrued (5 +2syn +11dex = 18), which is more than enough for setting all deadlies except gas types where only 15 ranks is needed.  To set deadly gas, you'd need modified 25 ranks. That would require 12 allocated instead of 5.

17 ranks in Disable Traps results in a final level of 21 with the synergy and INT mod (17 + 2syn + 2int), exactly enough to recover all deadlies except those lame gas types. To recover deadly gas, you'd need 5 more ranks, a total of 22 ranks allocated.  Only 16 modified ranks are needed to disarm deadly gas, so at least they can be deactivated where they lie.

So with the "economy" trap management package, you will save 12 skill points for other use.

Don't forget about Take 20 when you try to figure what DCs you can handle.  That means the Set Trap final ability (18) can set traps up to DC 38.  Deadly gas DC is 45 for comparison reasons.  Likewise, a Disable Trap final ability of 21 will result in a level of 41 with the Take 20.  That's good enough to disarm all non-epic traps but since recovery costs 10 points, will only recover DC 31 which just so happens to handle all non-epic traps except the gas ones.

Now for the kicker... Search.  That's a dice roll... so no Take 20.

To locate an epic trap requires a minimum of 23 modified ranks which will only spot the trap with a roll of 20 (5% chance every 6 secs).  To spot epic traps immediately (i.e. any dice roll will succeed), you'd need to max Search at 43 minus INT mod, in this case, 41 ranks.

So Search becomes absolutely the most crucial trap skill for an epic trapper.  If you can't spot it, you can't do doodly squat about it, right?  And rogues are the only class that can spot them anyway (though some custom environments may have altered the AD&D ruleset to allow assassins the same priviledge) so it really pays to have a trap specialist in your party.  Those epics can kill an entire party with a single trigger!

My non-epic rogues try to keep Fox pots handy, especially before the skills have developed adequately.  That +2 bonus can help spot, disable and recover DCs that would otherwise be just out of reach.  Likewise with Cat pots with Locks and Set Trap.

But this fellow is basically a kama monk with some roguish training so we will need to cross epic traps off his repertoire.  Well, not completely.  It just so happens that unless the spell has been altered by custom script, a scroll of Find Traps, a very inexpensive one, will locate and disarm even epic traps.  So there is still hope, through UMD, of dealing with epic trap threats.  But naturally, you would need to be either experienced in an area or clairvoyant to put that spell to use else it will cost a small fortune to be casting Find Traps around every corner (plus any non-epic traps will no longer be able to be recovered *all goes poof*).

That's probably more information about traps than you would ever desire but at least it is one spot now (well, actually 2 spots counting my trap guide).  Now you have been officially notified.

To recover deadly gas, you'd need 5 more ranks, a total of 22 ranks allocated.  Only 16 modified ranks are needed to disarm deadly gas, so at least they can be deactivated where they lie.

According to the NwN Wiki the DCs of disarming standard deadly traps are:
Electrical, fire, gas and spike: 36
Acid blob and tangle: 31
Negative and holy: 26
Sonic, frost and acid splash: 22
With "take 20" you need 16 modified ranks to disarm the hardest ones, and 11, 6 and 2 to disarm the other groups.
Add 10 ranks if you want to recover them.

Note that if the traps are set by a trapper, you must add their set trap skill to the DC.
Also note that sometimes the mod designer gives traps a custom DC.

posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote:
Essentially, once Epic Dodge is achieved, my next priority was to reach Monk 20. Primarily for Empty Body (at M18), for the undispellable 50% concealment, and Perfect Self (at M20) for immunity to mind spells; but alongside that there are the improvements to speed and AC, as well as more FoBs. Taking the two CoT levels earlier would bring +1 to Saves and faster access to Epic Prowess (and getting 4 more HP earlier, of course). Oh, and Divine Wrath, but this is not a positive CHA build, so... To be honest, the bonus feat and bump to saves are the only reasons CoT 5 and 6 are there at all - they bring more to the party than would Rogue 14 and 15 (barring, I suppose, an extra 1d6 Sneak Attack), or Monk 22 and 23.
Okay,  I see what concerned you more than the saves now... XP penalty.  Otherwise, you'd be using Fighter levels for specialization.  Typically, when making the choice for CoT, saves are the impetus because you lose a feat going that route.  But fair enough.  If Monk 18 is high priority, some delay is warranted.  Thing is, ImpInvis, though dispellable, can't be dispelled until your toon can be targeted.  And you can always reach into your stack and read another scroll even in that situation.  The foes that will be attacking (and missing) your PC up close and personal will probably not be dispelling at all, those being mainly caster types who will be attacking with spells, ignoring the benefits of any form of concealment.
As far as the trapping stuff is concerned, I'm a little baffled. I followed the discussions in posts #11 - #15 and built in your own recommendation (post #14) of putting 5 more points into Disable Trap, so now I'm a bit confused...
As well you should.  I think Mick (and myself) assumed you'd have high enough Set Trap ranks to actually use all those recovered strong and deadly gas.  At Disable Trap 21, you can disarm DCs up to 41, which is more than enough to disarm all gas types.  As it stands now, with Set Trap 18, there's no return on the extra 5 points investment beyond the economic one.
The gloves are a good tip, thanks. As it was, in testing, I keep the strongest variants of Monk-specific gloves I could find (for potential blunt weapon necessity), together with various others (DEX, Ogre Power, etc) in my pack, but don't recall finding those particular ones.
Here is a list of the +discipline gloves on the vanilla item palette (IIRC):
Gloves of Discipline +3
Nasher's Gloves of Discipline +5
Greater Gloves of Discipline +6
Epic Gloves of Discipline +30

The Epic variety come in several "skill flavors" to balance different classes:  Concentration +30, Spellcraft +30, Animal Handling (Empathy) +30, Minstrel (Perform) +30 and the dubious Swordplay (Parry) +30.  These can radically change the skill checks of a toon but tend to be made available mainly in high-magic environments (like HotU,  where I believe a few are preset drops in the Abandoned Entryway and perhaps even before).
I'll certainly reinforce my line that the spoiler is the "original draft", to make sure it's more clear. And I'll do my best to give the link - though I can't promise it'll be the pretty one!
No worries.  I have my paintbrush handy.
And finally, my Oxford English Dictionary has "levelled, levelling: US, leveled, leveling", so afraid not, my friend
I guess the Brits had to find somewhere to go with all those extra consonants that are part of their birthright.  All of a sudden I feel so multicultural with the knowledge.
